# tmforum

## Introduction

The key concepts described in this document provide a common language and understanding for the architect, other associates and business stakeholders. The foundational CONTEXTS are used to establish the enterprise's building blocks. These building blocks are fundamental to the Open Digital Framework (ODF) as they define key concepts that are used throughout ODF. The core frameworks that make up the TM Forum ODF, include the Business Process Framework (aka eTOM), the Information Framework (aka as SID), and the Functional Framework (derived from the previous TAM). The key principles provide the rules and guidelines that govern the application of key concepts in the Open Digital Framework. The rules are designed to reflect the values and goals of a digital organization, while providing direction and guidance for decision- making. These principles help to ensure consistency, alignment, and coherence across any architecture that aspires to align with the Open Digital Architecture (ODA). The section on method or methodology establish the processes and techniques that help an enterprise architect leverage the Open Digital Framework. They provide a structured and systematic approach to identify, analyze, design, and communicate the architecture. These methods or methodologies are here to help ensure quality, efficiency, and effectiveness of the target architecture of the organization. Models are the representations and artifacts that help the enterprise architect, design, document and communicate the architecture. In TM Forum, the Master Open Digital Architecture (MODA) is the definitive reference for ODA which provides the context and visualization of the structure, behavior, and relationships of the ODA business objects (architectural elements). Models help to ensure clarity, purpose, completeness and consistency of the architecture as they evolve through a maturation process which improves its reliability for TM Forum members. The adoption of the TM Forum core frameworks has the benefit of providing alignment with key industry standards and common ontology, in support of the enterprise's strategic and business goals. This can help boost both business and technical capabilities. All principles described in this document provide a foundational ground for the development of the enterprise's governance, rules and policies. TM Forum 2024. All Rights Reserved. # GB991 TM Forum Core Frameworks Concepts and Principles v24.5

## 1. Concepts and Definitions

structData.Description:
TM Forum's Core Frameworks is a suite of best practices and standards that provides the blueprint for effective, efficient business operations and enable a service-oriented, highly automated and efficient approach to business operations and application integration.

This Concepts and Principles document strives to enable the reader to get a complete point of view of the compilation and creation of the core Frameworks; (business process, Information and functional frameworks), explaining the reasoning to its construction.

The Open Digital Architecture (ODA) offers an industry-agreed blueprint, language and set of key design principles to follow. It will provide pragmatic pathways for the journey from maintaining monolithic, legacy software solutions, towards managing nimble, cloud-based capabilities that can be orchestrated using AI. It is a reference architecture that maps TM Forum's Open APIs and assets against technical and business platform functions.

The ODA Architecture Vision defines, using an analysis of the ODA business drivers:

  • The background to why a transformation is needed to the way OSS and BSS are imagined, to address significant and concurrent business, industry, and technology changes.
  • Eight key Architecture Framework artefact groupings that are needed to achieve business agility and zero touch automated operations which is based on TOGAF(TM) concepts.
  • Concepts and Principles and Vision that capture requirements, principles and an evolution path for the ODA Architecture.
  • Methods for Agile Model Driven Management to achieve agile service lifecycle management.
  • ODA Architecture Framework artefacts:
    • Standards specifications, capabilities based on standards, best practices, methodologies and tooling that provide the management support needed for a model driven agile service lifecycle; covering Business, Information Systems Architecture, Technical Architecture, Implementation and Deployment Architectures.
    • How to leverage and integrate, existing TM Forum artefacts to provide ODA artefacts and capabilities for each of the eight ODA Architecture Frameworks.

## 2.2. Architectural approach and design principles

The ODA Framework defines an approach to decoupling and separation of concerns which is essential to facilitate rapid independent evolution of solutions, whilst retaining Architectural cohesion, minimizing the complexity and cost of integration, and achieving implementation interoperability for e2e services. The ODA Architecture is captured in eight main artefact groupings which are inspired by TOGAF Enterprise Architecture best practice. Together these groupings provide a comprehensive Architecture for complete service lifecycle automation within an enterprise - such as a Communications Service Provider.TM Forum 2018. ### tmforum

Executive SummaryThis document describes reasons for defining an ODA Component (detailed in Open Digital Architecture Whitepaper), stemming from the need for an agile approach that encompasses business needs, network structure, and operational challenges. The document then describes the structure of a component, its sub-parts and their functionalities, as well as suggesting ways of exposing the functionalities. The document also addresses the lifecycle of the component and its composability aspects. Another section is devoted to the relation of ODA Components to the existing Frameworx assets, including to the Open APIs. # IG1171 ODA Component Definition v5.0.0

# tmforum

## Introduction

Building on TM Forum's rich history in leading IT and operational transformation, and on the success of a widely-used suite of standardized REST based Open APIs, this guide explains how we define ODA Components as software units that can be composed into systems or solutions. The Open Digital Architecture Whitepaper established the need for an "industry-agreed" digital architecture prescribing a set of industry agreed actions that enable, simplify and automate software systems based on standards. One of the key standards is the ODA Component. This document and the supplementary artifacts define the ODA Component and use. To fully realize the business requirement of multivendor solutions, ODA Components must support interoperability in much the same way that reusable components are offered in cloud marketplaces such as Microsoft Azure, IBM Cloud and Amazon Web Services etc. The definition of ODA Components follows the ODA Component principles to draw on best practices and modern concepts to effectively encapsulate the concept of componentization into ODA. answer.answerText:
## ODF: A Comprehensive Overview

The Open Digital Framework (ODF) is a comprehensive architecture framework developed by TM Forum to provide a common language and understanding for architects, stakeholders, and business associates. ODF's core frameworks include:

* **Business Process Framework (eTOM):** Defines the standard business processes for communications service providers (CSPs).
* **Information Framework (SID):** Provides a standardized information model for CSPs, ensuring consistent data representation across systems.
* **Functional Framework:** Derived from the previous TAM (Telecommunications Application Map), it outlines the functional components and their relationships within a CSP's IT landscape.

ODF also establishes key principles that guide the application of these concepts. These principles ensure consistency, alignment, and coherence across architectures that aim to align with the Open Digital Architecture (ODA). Additionally, ODF provides methods and methodologies to help enterprise architects leverage the framework effectively. These methods offer a structured approach to identify, analyze, design, and communicate the architecture.

Models, such as the Master Open Digital Architecture (MODA), serve as representations and artifacts to support the design, documentation, and communication of the architecture. MODA provides a definitive reference for ODA, visualizing the structure, behavior, and relationships of ODA business objects. 

**Benefits of Adopting ODF:**

* **Alignment with Industry Standards:** ODF aligns with key industry standards and common ontology, supporting an organization's strategic and business goals.
* **Enhanced Business and Technical Capabilities:** Adoption of ODF can boost both business and technical capabilities by providing a standardized framework for architecture development.
* **Governance, Rules, and Policies:** The principles outlined in ODF provide a foundation for developing the organization's governance, rules, and policies.

**ODA Architecture Vision:**

The ODA Architecture Vision defines eight main artefact groupings that provide a comprehensive architecture for complete service lifecycle automation within an enterprise. These groupings include:

* **ODA Concepts & Principles:** Documents the architectural principles, concepts, and requirements for each ODA Framework grouping.
* **ODA Architecture Vision:** Defines the eight ODA Architecture Framework groupings and provides a definition of the required artefacts, including specifications, capabilities, best practices, methods/methodologies, metrics, code, and tooling.
* **Agile and Model Driven Management:** Defines the requirements, modelling, and tooling approach for ODA lifecycle management, enabling business agility.
* **ODA Business Architecture:** Describes product and/or service strategy, organizational, functional, process, information, and geographic aspects of the business environment.
* **ODA Information Systems Architecture (ISA):** Provides the Functional Architecture and concepts of Data and Applications Architecture.

## ODA: A Blueprint for Modernizing Telecom IT and Networks

Open Digital Architecture (ODA) is a standardized cloud-native enterprise architecture blueprint designed to help Communication Service Providers (CSPs), suppliers, and system integrators (SIs) modernize their IT and network systems. By adopting ODA, CSPs can create new and differentiated services that improve productivity, reduce maintenance and integration costs, and enhance customer experience. 

ODA replaces traditional Operations and Business Support Systems (OSS/BSS) with a new approach that simplifies design, modernizes build, and automates operation. This approach enables CSPs to become more agile, efficient, and customer-centric. 

**Key Components of ODA:**

* **Open APIs:** ODA provides a set of standardized Open APIs that enable interoperability and collaboration between CSPs, suppliers, and SIs. These APIs define how different components interact and exchange data, making it easier to build and integrate new services. 
* **ODA Components:** ODA Components are self-describing, deployable software modules that encapsulate specific functionalities. They are built on open standards like Docker and Kubernetes and include Telco-domain knowledge and metadata. This metadata describes the component's core function, notification/reporting, security, and management functions. 
* **ODA Canvas:** The ODA Canvas is a platform that provides a testing environment for ODA Components. It allows developers to test and validate the deployment of components before deploying them in production environments. 
* **Governance:** ODA Governance ensures that solutions adhere to ODA principles throughout the project lifecycle. This includes activities like conformance testing, security assessments, and data governance. 

**Benefits of ODA:**

* **Improved Agility:** ODA enables CSPs to respond quickly to market changes and customer demands. 
* **Enhanced Customer Experience:** ODA facilitates the development of innovative services that improve customer satisfaction. 
* **Reduced Costs:** ODA simplifies design, build, and operation, leading to lower maintenance and integration costs. 
* **Increased Efficiency:** ODA automates operations, making CSPs more efficient and productive. 
* **Collaboration and Innovation:** ODA promotes collaboration between CSPs, suppliers, and SIs, fostering innovation and accelerating concept-to-cash. 

**Getting Started with ODA:**

TM Forum provides a comprehensive set of resources to help organizations adopt ODA. This includes training and certification programs, interactive learning modules, and support services. Additionally, the ODA interactive map provides access to a vast library of industry-created assets, including the business process framework, design principles, and specifications for standardized components and Open APIs.

chunkInfo.content: The business drivers and conceptual model for ODA Components is described in IG1171 ODA Component Definition. The ODA Component concept builds on top of open standards like Docker and Kubernetes, and adds Telco-domain knowledge and meta-data. The starting point for building an ODA component is containerized, micro-service software described in a kubernetes manifest YAML file. To turn this into an ODA Component we will: Add meta-data to the Kubernetes manifest describing the Core Function, Notification/Reporting, Security Function and Management Function of the software component. Add labels to all the standard Kubernetes resources to label them as belonging to the component. Test the deployment of the Component in an operating platform that has the ODA Canvas installed (for example the TM FOrum Open-Digital Lab). See the Getting Started section to see how to install the ODA Canvas onto a kubernetes cluster environmnet. Step 1: ODA-Component Metadata This guide has been updated to conform to the v1beta2 component specification. The ODA-Component metadata contains all the Telco-domain knowledge that makes the component a self-describing deployable software module. From IG1171 ODA Component Definition, this meta-data describes the Open-APIs, event data schemas as well as security and management & operations for the component. The meta-data is defined using a Kubernetes CustomResourceDefinition.

chunkInfo.content: It describes the list of APIs and/or events that the component exposes as well as the APIs and/or events that it is dependant on. The definitions within the publishedEvents and subscribedEvents are experimental at this point, and we will modify and enhance them as we build-out the ODA Canvas and assemble a representative set of ODA Components. The current definition has: an implementation which links to the Kubernetes service that implements the API or event, including the port where the http service is exposed. The path shows the API resource end-point, and can be used, for example, to automatically configure any API Gateway that is included as part of the Canvas. Note that the path points to the root of the API (and you need to append the relevant path from the swagger document to get to an implemented API resource). The specification points to the swagger documentation for the API. The Component CTK (Compliance Test Kit) will look inside this swagger for the basePath determine which Open-API CTK to execute for that API. The basePath is of format "/tmf-api/productCatalogManagement/v4/" which shows it is a tmf-api for productCatalogManagement with major version 4 .

BDD allows you to specify the desired behavior of software through examples in plain language that both business stakeholders and technical teams can understand. These examples are written in a format known as Gherkin, which uses Given-When-Then syntax to describe test scenarios. Given: This part of the syntax sets the scene for the scenario. It describes the initial context or the pre-conditions of the system before the key action is performed. Example: “Given the user is logged into their account” When: This section describes the event or the action that triggers the scenario. It is the key action that the user performs or the event that occurs within the system. Example: “When the user clicks on the delete account button” Then: This final part specifies the expected outcome or the post-conditions following the action described in the When section. It clearly defines what success (or sometimes failure) looks like. Example: “Then the user's account is deactivated and the user is redirected to the homepage” By defining the desired behavior of the software through examples, you can then implement automated tests to verify that the software behaves as expected. This approach helps to ensure that the software meets the requirements of the business and that it continues to do so as it evolves over time.

ODF stands for Open Digital Framework. It's a comprehensive architecture framework developed by TM Forum to provide a common language and understanding for architects, stakeholders, and business associates in the telecommunications industry. 

Here are some key aspects of ODF:

* **Core Frameworks:** ODF includes frameworks like eTOM (Business Process Framework), SID (Information Framework), and the Functional Framework. These frameworks define standard business processes, information models, and functional components for communication service providers (CSPs).
* **Principles:** ODF establishes principles that guide the application of these frameworks, ensuring consistency, alignment, and coherence across architectures.
* **Methods and Methodologies:** ODF provides methods and methodologies to help enterprise architects effectively leverage the framework. These methods offer a structured approach to identify, analyze, design, and communicate the architecture.
* **Models:** ODF uses models like MODA (Master Open Digital Architecture) to represent and document the architecture. MODA provides a definitive reference for ODA, visualizing the structure, behavior, and relationships of ODA business objects.

The goal of ODF is to enable CSPs to adopt a standardized approach to architecture development, leading to benefits like:

* **Alignment with Industry Standards:** ODF aligns with key industry standards, supporting an organization's strategic and business goals.
* **Enhanced Business and Technical Capabilities:** ODF can boost both business and technical capabilities by providing a standardized framework for architecture development.
* **Governance, Rules, and Policies:** ODF principles provide a foundation for developing an organization's governance, rules, and policies.

ODF is closely related to Open Digital Architecture (ODA), which is a cloud-native enterprise architecture blueprint designed to help CSPs modernize their IT and network systems. ODF provides the foundational frameworks and principles that underpin ODA.
